name: Jacob Hawkins
review_text:
DODGY DODGY DODGY

HOTHAM ENCOURAGES YOU TO SKI WHILE ILL! THEY DO NOT OFFER ANY REFUNDS FOR PEOPLE WHO ARE UNWELL AND UNABLE TO SKI AND ENCOURAGE YOU TO VISIT WHILE ILL!

Hotham is a dodgy resort operated by the company Vail which is a company with no interest in people's wellbeing. Structured to avoid complaints I watched several people be rejected by Hotham to go deal with Epic and Hotham actively didn't help several paying customers with issues with there lessons while I watched and was also not helped...

I recently took a family trip to Hotham. My 11 month old daughter contracted gastro while visiting and we had to go to hospital on our first night. The local nurse and doctors told us that there was a fairly large and severe gastro outbreak causing people to present at hospital and many were coming from Hotham. No such warning from the resort though.

When I was unable to utilise my ski lifts and lessons they refused to provide me a refund and said I had to be sick for over 30 days for them to provide a refund.

I am not wealthy and am a disability support worker and when a company who makes that much money doesn't provide a refund for services they didn't provide I see red. I cannot afford another trip to Hotham and they made it absolutely clear that they would prefer me to ski and spread the sickness than to come to any fair conclusions. As a result I went skiing on the last day after they refused my refund and informed everyone I could that I was unwell and to keep a distance.

They don't care if there resorts make no money, if they ruin pristine natural environments and charge exorbitant fees for lift tickets and offer no refunds if you do not use them due to sickness. They charge $150 a day for those lift tickets and they run regardless. Dodgy as. Skiing cost me about $400 a day from lift tickets to gear hire and lessons and I just hoped to recouped $150 per day of that but they refuse. ACCC here I come.

I will leave a review like this on every Vail resort every week until they respond and I will keep smashing them with complaints and everything I can. Dodgy, dodgy dodgy....

name: Roni Dattani
review_text:
Amazing ski resort - plenty of blue hills, and black hills. Wish it had a few more greens, but big D and the Summit almost always run (they are green hills, ideal for learning and beginners) - where as blues and blacks sometimes shut down due to weather/not enough snow. The parking is a bit chaotic and spread out, but there are bus stops running regularly along the lots to take you around the ski resort.

Mornings are always hectic and you may have to wait for 2-3 buses. The drivers really should call out the stops as the windows fog up and they sometimes skip stops. The parking is usually a bit muddy on wet days and the food selection at the cafes is limited to mostly fried foods, over priced and unhealthy. They also need a few more washroom spots throughout the area, but in the grand scheme of things, if trying to get some skiing done in Victoria, this is definitely a must do place and overall probably the best in Australia!

The biggest improvement from past years is if doing an adult lesson and dropping your kids to their lesson, the drop off is now the same location - Hotham Central - and ski rentals are still reasonably priced. Their cancellation policy is a bit unforgiving (refunds only come with medical certificates) but snow credit is offered w 48 hr notice... and is good for remaining season +1 yr so makes it easier to pre-book with some confidence that you won't lose money. Good for locals, but not good for international folks who may never come back!

Their app is good, only problem is the lift closure status is not updated very quickly at times of strong winds or inclement weather conditions.

A great ski resort, totally worth visiting when weather is good. I suggest a hearty breakfast, bring some healthy snacks of your own and keep in a locker and grab dinner outside the resort.

review_text:
Extremely disappointing experience at Mt Hotham.
Nearly 95% of the staff seemed to be young, untrained backpackers with little to no service skills. The food across cafes and restaurants was overpriced and lacked any real value -- honestly, zero bang for your buck.

By the time you factor in lift passes, gear rental, snow chains, and parking, it adds up fast -- but sadly, the experience doesn't deliver. Despite multiple fireplaces around the resort, not a single one was on... in the middle of winter. At a ski resort. Makes no sense.

We booked three full days of snowboarding lessons for the kids -- 28 children and only two very young, clearly inexperienced instructors. Total chaos and a complete waste of money.

Very little presence from senior management. Overall, avoid this place. There are far better ski resorts in Victoria where your time and money will go further.

review_text:
We had a fantastic time--this is a perfect spot for families. When we visited, the area was blanketed in snow and fog, creating a truly magical atmosphere.

Snow chains are essential and can be rented from Hoys Skis in Harrietville, just before the climb. You're not required to fit them unless it's snowing, but it's mandatory to carry them in your vehicle. Note that chains may not be suitable for vehicles with tyres larger than 19 inches.Toboggans are also available for hire and are a big hit with the kids!

Parking can be a bit challenging, but free shuttle buses run frequently between key areas. A resort entry permit is required (around $70), and it's best to book it online in advance. The drive up from the valley to the resort is quite steep, with a speed limit of 40 km/h.

review_text:
This was our first snow trip and it definitely didn't disappoint. We live in Newcastle NSW and we have 3 kids aged 7,8,& 10. We visited in the last week of July. The kids did 2 days of ski lessons and 2 days of free skiing at Big D. They loved every minute and they wouldn't let us leave until the lifts stopped for the day. My wife and I did a couple of 2hr lessons which was enough for us to feel comfortable on the blue runs.
We had 40cm of snow while we were there and the runs were well groomed.
The lift staff and instructors were very helpful, (with it being our first time).
We tried 2 of the restaurants, which were great and the cafe at Big D was average but not bad.
If you get there before 9am, close parking is pretty easy to find and if U get there later the bus that runs around to the different runs is very good and has lots of stops.
We also met the amazing people at howling huskies and the kids had a dog sled ride. Most of their dogs are rescues which is cool.
The only downside is the price. We got gifted accommodation from my parents as a Christmas present at Wyndham and borrowed ski clothes for the kids from friends, but with 4 days lift passes, 2 days of lessons, ski, boot and helmet hire, park entry and snow chain hire it was about $6000, so it may be a few years before we get back.
Overall I think we have caught the bug and will definitely visit Hotham again.

There were no slopes on Hotham that we felt suitable for a beginner. The "carpet" was an absolute joke, a sheer drop with no space to turn and all of the beginners in this area just fell down before they hit the barriers and likely hurt themselves. We asked some of the instructors for advice on which slopes were better for beginners and were sent to Big D carpet. When we got there we were told the only way to get to the carpet was to walk up the slopes...after a painstaking 30 minute climb we were told we couldn't be there as they had too many children then today and sent back down. As we ski'd back down the mountain - badly - An instructor pulled up with a group of children and instructed the children that we were "gerrys" and that we didn't belong on the slope!

In summary, the experience was not one that we would go out of our way to repeat and that their own instructor made comments to a group of young children about how we didn't belong there was appalling.

name: Matias Wulf
review_text:
I had an extremely disappointing experience at Hotham, and I feel compelled to share my concerns. Over two weeks ago, I reported a serious safety issue and the lack of support from Hotham staff, but I have yet to receive any communication from them. This lack of response shows a disturbing disregard for customer experiences and safety.

On Saturday, July 20th, the road conditions were hazardous due to a snowstorm, but the Hotham staff failed to provide adequate warnings or information. Despite having access to weather forecasts and real-time road reports, they only told us to use chains starting from Bay 6, without mentioning how bad the conditions really were. The visibility was less than 10 meters, the road lines were invisible, and the snow wasn't properly cleared, making driving extremely dangerous.

Our car spun 360 degrees even though we were driving at just 10 km per hour, and there were at least four accidents on the way down. When we expressed our concerns to the reception staff, they were unhelpful and suggested we check the website for accommodation, stating they couldn't assist further.

This experience indicates that Hotham prioritizes revenue over the safety and well-being of their customers. The lack of communication and support during such a dangerous situation is unacceptable. I urge future visitors to consider these safety concerns and the apparent lack of customer care before visiting Hotham.

review_text:
Guys, this place is NOT for adult beginners.

We did some investigation prior to booking and were told by staff that Hotham is great for adult beginners, but it's definitely not.

The bottom of the summit run (where all adult lessons are held) is also where the run concludes, so experienced skiers are ZOOMING past you, and get impatient if you're in their way.

The area where you're learning is FULL of people learning, and also a thoroughfare for people ending the summit run, starting the summit run, and using both the chairlift and pommer. It's SO BUSY!

No room to learn properly, and our instructors kept getting bored and wanting to take us up the summit run, which is NOT appropriate for a fresh, super-beginner person.

Everyone who is learning is walking on top of one another. It's not a fun place to learn, and doesn't have enough green runs to accommodate all the beginners.

If you're an adult beginner, this is NOT the place for you.

Also, it's super, super, SUPER expensive. No half-day lift passes. Expensive lessons with (mostly) underexperienced, unmotivated instructors.

name: Tom Durrand
review_text: This climb is an absolute giant in the world of Australian cycling. 30.8 kilometres, this is the distance of Mt Hotham making it one of the biggest climbs Down Under distance wise, but the Col takes out the top spot in elevation gain being the highest paved climb in Australia. The road snakes around in a massive U shape, so at almost all times you can see the elusive  distance summit and it daunts you on how huge this mountain really is (but trust me it's worth the exertion to see those views!). There are two eminent steep sections of this big hill the first of the pair being The Meg: The Meg swims on to scene at five kilometres in with an average grade of about 8% maxing out at about 14%, nothing to deep just make sure you know your strokes! CRB hill: This section lasts for precisely 1.57 kilometres at an average gradient of 8.8%. Hopefully by now your in to a good rhythm knowing the finish is almost in your grasp, dancing on the pedals like Tadej Pogacar, but if not your in for a tough one. The views of this mountain are absolutely stunning from bottom to top, it's a beautiful part of the world. It is hard to beat this mountain, cycling heaven, ski resort, accommodation and cafes what more could you ask for 1857 meters in the air.
response_from_owner_text: Thanks for your review Tom bit more importantly CONGRATS on doing the climb by bike! We hope the views were worth it.

Went to Hotham recently without any skiing experience, and can say that it was an amazing stay. Skiing is not my thing, however the ski staff were helpful and polite and we're open to any questions. Food service was absolutely amazing and all food was delicious. Bus provided easy access to whole resort and there were good facilities for all ages making it perfect for families. If there were to be one complaint it is that the on site supermarkets were extremely expensive ($8 for a 2l bottle of milk) so it is advised to bring supplies.
Note: make sure to fill the petrol tank before starting the climb as there are no fuel stations on the mountain.

name: Jackson Richards
review_text:
Not terribly impressed, cost was incredible ($138 for the day plus $50 to park) and the snow conditions were pretty substandard.

With the forecasting available I would have thought they'd be out the night before it bucketed down/went below freezing to groom the slush into some semblance of a run.

But instead there were big patches of ice on green and blue runs, random sticks/leaves throughout the snow from past days of wind and to top it off a number of blue and blacks had signs indicating 'insufficient cover - unmarked hazards ahead' despite their website claiming over a metre of snowbase...

Their snow reports are useless too, better to stick with the BOM and roll the dice on what's actually on the slope.
